results.title: Unraveling the Mysteries Hidden in Vast Glacier Caves
results.abstract: A group of scientists and adventure athletes are venturing into icy labyrinths to study their relationships with glacial melting and climate change.

multimedia.caption: During the summer, moulins are filled with raging waterfalls. Fall’s cooler temperatures shut off surface melting and allow a brief window for glacier cave exploration before moulins become plugged with winter’s drifting snow. Here, Will Gadd finishes climbing out of a moulin during the Red Bull Beneath the Ice expedition to explore and study Greenland’s glacier caves.
multimedia.copyright: Jason Gulley

results.title: The Legacy of America’s Post-9/11 Turn to Torture
results.abstract: Twenty years after the attacks, the United States is still grappling with the consequences of brutal interrogations carried out in the name of national security.

results.title: Amid cries of tyranny, Britain cancels any plan to require vaccine passports.

results.title: Israel threatens to charge scores who returned from a Ukraine pilgrimage using faked coronavirus test results.
results.abstract: Officials said that more than 1,500 cases were identified among the 17,000 travelers who flew back on Thursday and Friday, and that more than 150 had hidden positive test results and obtained falsified negative results to travel on.

results.title: Joseph Brodsky Slept Here. The Great Poet’s Cranky Neighbor Couldn’t Care Less.
results.abstract: After a decades-long standoff with the last resident of a communal apartment, a private museum has finally opened in Brodsky’s shared home in St. Petersburg, a rare grass-roots victory in Russia.

results.title: Gilbert Seltzer, Soldier in the World War II ‘Ghost Army,’ Dies at 106
results.abstract: He was one of the last survivors of a band of Army con artists who duped German forces with their arsenal of fakery, including inflatable tanks and scripted radio transmissions.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
The Ghost Army of World War II: How One Top-Secret Unit Deceived the Enemy with Inflatable Tanks, Sound Effects, and Other Audacious Fakery (Book)

multimedia.caption: Gilbert Seltzer in 1942, after graduating from officer candidate school in Fort Belvoir, Va. During World War II he belonged to a secret Army unit, skilled at creating the illusion that American troops were where they weren’t, that came to be known as the Ghost Army.
multimedia.copyright: via Seltzer family

results.title: The U.S. is falling to the lowest vaccination rates of the world’s wealthiest democracies.
results.abstract: The United States has the lowest rate of partial vaccination among the Group of 7 nations, and is all but certain to rank last in full vaccination shortly, as Japan rapidly increases its pace while the U.S.’s slows.

results.title: At Pro-Taliban Protest, a Symbol of America’s Lost Influence: Faces Obscured by Veils
results.abstract: Several hundred women wore the head-to-toe garments at a pro-Taliban demonstration on Sept. 11. The march was a reminder of how after years of war, Afghanistan’s women are again at the mercy of the militants.
results.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Victor J. Blue

multimedia.caption: A Taliban fighter stands guard while women, many wearing burqas, march in support of the Taliban in Kabul on Saturday.
multimedia.copyright: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

results.title: Abimael Guzmán, Leader of Guerrilla Group That Terrorized Peru, Dies at 86
results.abstract: Mr. Guzmán’s Maoist movement, Shining Path, killed tens of thousands in the 1980s and ’90s. He sought to bring the world to a “higher stage of Marxism.”

multimedia.caption: Abimael Guzmán, founder of the Shining Path guerrilla movement, at a court hearing in Lima, Peru, in 2018.

results.title: Unearthed at a British Golf Course: A Log Coffin From the Bronze Age
results.abstract: Workers digging in a pond at the Tetney Golf Club discovered a waterlogged coffin containing the remains of a man who archaeologists said was buried about 4,000 years ago.

multimedia.caption: Ian Panter, the head of conservation at York Archaeological Trust, with the Bronze Age log coffin discovered on a British golf course in 2018.

results.title: For a Fractured Israel, a Film Offers Ominous Lessons From Ancient Past
results.abstract: An animated epic depicting a Jewish civil war and the destruction of the Second Temple 2,000 years ago is being seen as a warning in a deeply divided country.

results.title: Quandary at U.N.: Who Speaks for Myanmar and Afghanistan?
results.abstract: Governments of the two countries have been toppled by pariah regimes. Will they get seats at the world’s biggest diplomatic table anyway?
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

results.title: ‘It’s a Godsend’: 9-Cent Taxi Rides in Rural South Korea
results.abstract: One county’s plan to help older, carless citizens stuck in remote villages proved wildly popular and has been copied across South Korea, revolutionizing public transportation in the countryside.

multimedia.caption: Cheon Song-ja, 78; Hong Seok-soon, 77; and Na Jeong-soon, 85, on a taxi trip that would cost them pennies.
multimedia.copyright: Jean Chung for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Everything Changed Overnight’: Afghan Reporters Face an Intolerant Regime
results.abstract: The Taliban promised to respect press freedoms, but the new government has already showed signs of repression, and has even physically assaulted Afghan journalists.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
